ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

INSTITUTE OF ESTATE AGENTS
(Waiver of agency commission)


    The following question stood in the name of Dr Teo Ho Pin -

    1. To ask the Minister for Trade and Industry whether his Ministry will take a stand on the recent move by the Institute of Estate Agents to restrict its members from waiving their agency commission.

    Mrs Lim Hwee Hua (Marine Parade): Question No. 1.

    The Minister for Trade and Industry (BG George Yong-Boon Yeo): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, although we do not have specific legislation against price fixing or cartels, the Government's policy is to discourage them. For markets to work well there must be free competition, not collusion or price fixing.

    That is why the Government has been progressively liberalising sectors such as telecommunications, finance and power. In the areas where prices have traditionally been fixed, such as conveyancing fees, stockbroking commissions and interest rates for chequing accounts, we have now allowed the market to set prices. In other words, the Government strongly encourages price competition. For instance, we facilitate parallel imports of motorcars.

    In promoting greater competition in our economy, Singapore has not taken the approach of implementing an umbrella competition law as in OECD countries because it is complicated and can reduce business flexibility. MTI has found moral suasion effective when the occasional case occurs. We will, however, review the need for legislation.

SINGAPORE AIRLINES AND COST OF TICKET
(Name of passenger's contact person and telephone number)


    The following question stood in the name of Mr Chiam See Tong -

Column: 1210



    2. To ask the Minister for Communications and Information Technology (a) whether he will suggest to Singapore Airlines that every passenger be required to give the name of the contact person and his telephone number at the check-in counter before a flight departure; and (b) why does an SIA ticket cost more than that of any other airline for a Singaporean flying to the same destination from Singapore.

    Mr Leong Horn Kee (Bishan-Toa Payoh): Question No. 2, Sir.

    The Minister for Communications and Information Technology (Mr Yeo Cheow Tong): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, SIA relies on the contact numbers provided by passengers at the point of booking their tickets if they have to contact the passenger or the next-of-kin. Currently, it is not the standard industry practice for airlines to take down the particulars of passengers' next-of-kin. Singapore Airlines would have to assess how to reconcile the need for essential passenger information without compromising its speed and efficiency. It would also have to take into account the sensitivity of some passengers who might not wish to provide personal information to the airline. Nonetheless, I can convey Mr Chiam's suggestion to SIA.

    As for the question on SIA's ticket pricing, the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore does not intervene in the pricing policies of airlines operating in Singapore. Singapore is a major international aviation hub with over 60 airlines operating here. Airlines price their tickets based on commercial considerations and consumers are free to choose the airlines which best suit their requirements in terms of services, price, routing and flight frequencies, etc. The prices of airline tickets are therefore determined by market forces.

    Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Does the Minister not think that something is amiss when Singaporeans are made to pay higher prices than foreigners when they buy SIA tickets in Singapore?

Column: 1211



    Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, foreigners buying tickets in Singapore pay the same price as any Singaporean. The market forces are at play. There are many airlines operating out of Singapore, and there are many airlines flying the same routes as SIA. So consumers should choose carefully.

    Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, but in the case of SIA, Singaporeans prefer to fly by SIA and they are made to pay a higher price. In a way, they are forced to take other airlines. Do you not think there is something wrong there?

    Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, I do not think anybody forces Singaporeans to fly on either SIA or any other airline. In fact, many Singaporeans fly on non-SQ flights. I think the market is a very open one. As with every product and every service, if a product or service is of a higher quality, normally a premium will be applied, and we leave it to the market to determine whether a premium is applicable. In the case of airline tickets, the same mechanism applies.

    Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, that is the point. When Singaporeans fly in other airlines, and they start to talk with their fellow passengers, and they found out that we are from Singapore, they would wonder, "How come you never fly your own SIA airline?" What are you going to tell the other person? Tell him that we have to pay more? Does it not sound rather embarrassing for Singaporeans?

    Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: I do not think there is anything embarrassing about buying non-Singapore products.

STAMP DUTIES (AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

    The Second Minister for Finance (Mr Lim Hng Kiang): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

Introduction

    The Bill seeks to amend the Stamp Duties Act to give legislative authority to the tax changes announced in Budget 2000.

Rationale

    The current section 15 of the Stamp Duties Act provides stamp duty relief for corporate restructuring and mergers. Relief from ad valorem duty is given based on the principle that there will be no substantial change in ownership of the transferred assets. As section 15 is a relieving section, several conditions have been set for the concession.

    In recognition that companies restructure and merge to obtain greater synergy, achieve cost competitiveness and deliver better products and services to increasingly sophisticated consumers, Dr Richard Hu announced in Budget 2000 that the conditions for section 15 relief will be relaxed so that more companies can enjoy the tax savings.

    Dr Hu also announced that relief would be granted to a transfer of assets between associated companies. This relief was previously not available.

    To effect the above changes, the Bill repeals the current section 15 and introduces a new section 15 to allow ad valorem duty relief for:

Column: 1213



    (a) a transfer of the undertaking or shares in respect of a scheme for the reconstruction or amalgamation of companies; and

    (b) the transfer, conveyance or assignment of any beneficial interest in any asset between associated companies.

    In order to prevent abuse and to limit the concession to deserving restructuring and merger schemes, we have imposed qualifying conditions. The conditions to be imposed have been announced via a circular issued by the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore. The expanded relief scheme has been effected administratively since 1st July 2000.

    The response to the expanded relief scheme has been encouraging. We will continue to monitor industry trends and amend the conditions when necessary, to make sure that they remain relevant to the business community.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Bill accordingly read a Second time and committed to a Committee of the whole House.

    The House immediately resolved itself into a Committee on the Bill. - [Mr Lim Hng Kiang].

    Bill considered in Committee; reported without amendment; read a Third time and passed.

GOODS AND SERVICES TAX (AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

Introduction

    The Bill seeks to amend the Goods and Services Tax Act to give legislative effect to the change in tax treatment for trustee services announced in the 2000 Budget Statement. It also incorporates two other amendments to the Goods and Services Tax Act.

Column: 1214



Change in tax treatment announced in the 2000 Budget Statement

    I have earlier in the fiscal year 2000 Budget announced that trustee services supplied by trustees situated in Singapore that satisfy the following two conditions can be zero-rated. Firstly, at least 80% of the value of the trust property is contributed by overseas settlors, and secondly, at least 80% of the beneficiaries and settlors are non-residents of Singapore.

    A cardinal principle underlying the Goods and Services Tax is that it is a tax on domestic consumption of goods and services. Before the above changes were announced, the provision of trustee services by a trustee to the trust is standard-rated even if the settlors and beneficiaries of the trust are all or mostly foreigners, as the trustee representing the trust is situated in Singapore. In such cases, there is in-principle no domestic consumption, as the recipients of the services are in fact the beneficiaries and the settlors who are foreigners. Therefore, to put Singapore trustees on a more competitive footing with offshore trustees, I have decided to zero-rate the trustee services provided by the local trustee for such cases. Section 21 of the GST Act will be amended for this purpose.

Changes to the Act not arising from the 2000 Budget Statement

    In addition to this amendment, the following amendments will also be made to the GST Act.

    Sections 33(3) of the GST Act will be amended to specify the rules to be used by a local taxable person who is entrusted by his overseas clients to import and supply the goods in Singapore. The rules will provide greater clarity to businesses to determine the circumstances in which they can claim the GST paid on the goods imported and to account for GST on any supply of such goods in Singapore, as if he is the person making the supply. Arising from this, a consequential amendment will also be made to section 33(1).

Column: 1215

These amendments will serve to provide clarity to businesses.

    A new section 34A will be inserted to the Act to deem input tax as being deducted by the transferee for assets transferred under a "Transfer of Business as a Going Concern (TOGC)" arrangement. This is to place a transferee who acquires assets under a TOGC on par with other GST-registered traders who purchase assets and pay the GST.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Bill accordingly read a Second time and committed to a Committee of the whole House.

    The House immediately resolved itself into a Committee on the Bill. - [Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau].

CUSTOMS (AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    This Bill seeks to amend the Customs Act to give legislative effect to a change of definition of customs duty to exclude excise duty. It also incorporates three other amendments to the Customs Act.

Re-definition of Customs Duty

    Currently, our Customs Act defines customs duty as `any import or excise duty imposed by or under this Act'. The common international practice is that customs duty refers exclusively to tariffs applied on imported goods for protective and other trade policy purposes. Our current definition of customs duty may therefore cause confusion to our trading partners since it also includes excise duty which is applied in a non-discriminatory manner on imported goods and locally manufactured products for fiscal and other domestic policy purposes.

Column: 1216



    To make clear to our trading partners the respective purposes of our customs duty and excise duty, our definition of customs duty should be amended to exclude excise duty. In this connection, a new subsection 10(1A) will also be inserted to state clearly that excise duty shall be imposed in a non-discriminatory basis regardless of the place of origin or manufacture of the goods. For equal treatment of imported goods and locally manufactured goods, section 22 will also be amended so that the same basis of valuation will be applied on imported goods and locally manufactured goods for the purposes of levying excise duty.

Other Changes to the Act

    In addition to the aforementioned amendments, the following amendments will also be made to the Customs Act.

    Currently, all sellers of liquors must apply for a licence. A new subsection 71(3A) would be inserted to empower the Minister to exempt any person from having to apply for a licence for the sale of liquors subject to conditions imposed by the Minister. This amendment will allow individuals who sell small quantities of liquors to be exempted from applying for a licence. An example would be a person who wants to auction a few bottles of his personal collection of wine through the Internet. We have decided to cap the sales limit at 9 litres per calendar year.

    Section 75 provides for specific duties and requirements to be imposed on persons licensed for the sale of intoxicating liquors. This section will be repealed. The new section 75 will enable the Minister to prescribe by regulations certain duties and requirements of persons licensed to sell liquors. This will give us the flexibility to revise those duties and requirements to keep up with changing circumstances without having to amend the Act.

    Lastly, a new section 90E will be inserted to require every importer and exporter of dutiable goods and his agents to retain specified documents relating to

Column: 1217

the goods for not less than seven years. This new section will facilitate the enforcement of other provisions of the Act.

    Sir, I beg to move.

Column: 1217

CENTRAL PROVIDENT FUND (AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

    The Minister for Manpower (Dr Lee Boon Yang): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    In August 2000, the Government announced that, with effect from 1st of January 2001, CPF members would be allowed to invest their Special Account savings in the lower-risk financial instruments that are suitable for retirement savings. The CPF (Amendment) Bill before the House today seeks to amend the CPF Act to allow for the withdrawal of moneys from the Special Account for approved investments. The Bill also seeks to amend the CPF Act to enable the implementation of new schemes announced by the Minister for Finance at the financial year 2000 Budget Statement and to give effect to other changes to better serve CPF members.

    First, on the investment of Special Account fund. Since its introduction in July 1977, the CPF Special Account had remained the most protected portion of a CPF member's savings. Over the years, we had gradually liberalised the CPF rules to allow members to use savings in their Ordinary Account to purchase homes, invest in shares, buy insurance policies, unit trusts, or even place in fixed deposits.

Column: 1218

Only the savings in the Special Account had remained untouched. Why? Because the Special Account was seen as a member's cash savings for his retirement. The Special Account complements the Minimum Sum Scheme. This is so because, for most of the CPF members, the cash needed to be set aside for the Minimum Sum would come largely from the Special Account savings. Most members by age 55 would have withdrawn a large part of the Ordinary Account savings to finance the purchase of their homes. Hence, the Special Account would provide most of the cash savings for their old-age needs.

    In November 1999, the Inter-Ministerial Committee on Ageing Population recommended that Special Account savings in excess of the Minimum Sum be allowed for investments in retirement-related instruments. The Committee concluded that there are in existence today adequate avenues for low risk long-term investments which can help CPF members to enhance their old-age cash savings. The Government accepted this recommendation to give CPF members the opportunity to earn higher returns on their retirement savings. On closer study, my Ministry concluded that by restricting the class of retirement-related instruments, we did not even require CPF members to lock up the Minimum Sum. In other words, it was possible to allow members to invest all of their Special Account savings in such a retirement-related instrument.

    However, the basic principle that the Special Account savings should not be exposed to high investment risk remains valid. Hence, such investment should not go to high risk high return speculative instruments. We have to make a risk/return trade-off and balance the goal of enabling CPF members to earn higher returns against the fact that the Special Account savings represent the basic safety net for many Singaporeans. The advantage of allowing all Special Account funds, including the Minimum Sum, for approved investments is to encourage our citizens to take greater responsibility for their old age security and to take financial planning more seriously.

Column: 1219



    Sir, to reduce the exposure of Special Account savings to investment risk, only lower-risk instruments would be allowed. Products that are suitable for investment using the Special Account savings include long-term bank deposits; deferred annuities; endowment insurance policies; Singapore Government/statutory board and other bonds guaranteed by the Government; and selected unit trusts and investment-linked insurance policies.

    The list of approved unit trusts and investment-linked insurance policies will be based on the lowest three tiers of the Risk Classification System adopted under the CPF Investment Scheme. These comprise mainly money market, fixed income and balanced funds. Higher risk unit trusts and investment-linked policies, comprising funds wholly or mainly invested in equities, will not be allowed under the scheme. CPF members are also not allowed to invest their Special Account savings in individual stocks and gold. This is to prevent their Special Account savings from being exposed to unhedged risks.

    Sir, as the CPF Act currently does not have any provision to allow the withdrawal of Special Account savings for investment, clause 4 of the Bill amends section 13(1) of the Act to allow moneys from the Special Account to be withdrawn for approved investments under existing section 77(1)(m). This will give CPF members wider access to more investment options. However, as with any investment, CPF members would have to exercise careful judgement and decide for themselves the level of risk that they are willing to take in their investment decision. If they take a long-term view and exercise prudence in their investments, they are likely to enhance their old-age savings to better meet retirement needs. But if CPF members do not wish to risk investing their CPF savings, they can keep their savings with the CPF Board which provides a guaranteed minimum return of 2 1/2% for savings in the Ordinary Account and 4% for savings in the Special Account.

    Sir, I will now touch on the amendments affecting the Budget 2000 measures.

Column: 1220

Currently, under the Minimum Sum Scheme, a member may, upon reaching age 55, leave his Minimum Sum with the CPF Board, deposit it with an approved bank or use it to buy an annuity from an insurance company. CPF savings in excess of the Minimum Sum can be withdrawn.

    To encourage more prudent financial planning with CPF savings, Finance Minister announced in the FY2000 Budget Statement that the current tax exemption for annuities bought with the Minimum Sum would be extended to annuities bought with CPF savings beyond the Minimum Sum. The same tax treatment would be accorded to interest income arising from CPF savings beyond the Minimum Sum deposited with approved banks.

    Clause 6 of the Bill introduces a new section 15B to provide that a member who is entitled to withdraw his CPF savings may set aside, in addition to the Minimum Sum, an additional sum and deposit it with any approved bank or use it to buy any approved annuity. CPF members will enjoy tax exemption on the monthly withdrawals from this additional sum set aside.

    In Finance Minister's FY2000 Budget Statement, he had also announced that the tax relief for cash top-ups for parents under the Minimum Sum Topping-Up Scheme would be extended to grandparents with effect from Year of Assessment 2001. Clause 7 amends section 18 of the CPF Act to extend the Minimum Sum Topping-Up Scheme to grandparents. This will help to strengthen the multi-generational family bonds and reinforce the Asian tradition of looking after our parents and grandparents in their old age. Clause 9 amends section 19 to provide for the monies paid to a member's grandparents' retirement account shall, on the grandparents' death, be returned to the account of the member who made the payment.

    Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I will now touch on the CPF Home Protection Insurance Scheme and the Dependant's Protection Insurance Scheme.

Column: 1221



    The CPF Home Protection Insurance Scheme was introduced to protect CPF members and their families from losing their HDB flats should the insured die or become permanently incapacitated before their housing loans are paid up. The Dependant's Protection Insurance Scheme aims to provide CPF members and their dependants with financial assistance in the event that the insured member becomes permanently disabled or die prematurely.

    Currently, under both insurance schemes, claims are not payable if the death or permanent injury of the insured member arising from deliberate self-injury occurs within 1 year from the date that he is insured under the schemes. The 1-year time bar is imposed to prevent abuse where a CPF member may intentionally join the schemes before he attempts to commit suicide. This policy is valid and will be continued.

    However, there are cases where the act of suicide is committed within the 1-year period but the death happens after the period. Claims for such cases should not be accepted, as the intention to inflict self-injury within the time bar has been made clear. Similarly, the 1-year time bar would apply in cases where the insured member's death or permanent incapacity was the result of his own intentional criminal act. In such cases, the CPF Board shall not be required to pay the insurance claims if the criminal act is committed within 1 year from the date that he is insured under the scheme(s). Clauses 14 and 16 of the Bill amend sections 36(5) and 49(4) of the Act to provide for the above.

    Let me qualify what I mean by intentional criminal act. I am not referring to minor offences or acts of negligence such as some offences committed while driving a car which could, in fact, result in the offender's injury or even death. In such cases, the CPF Board has been paying the claims and they will continue to do so. Intentional criminal act in this context

Column: 1222

means a premeditated act, which any citizen would know, will draw serious penalties such as drug trafficking, gang robbery and murder. For example, if a member was involved in robbing a bank and was shot dead in the exchange of fire with the police, the 1-year time bar will apply. Or, if he participated in gang robbery and murdered a victim in the course of the robbery and was subsequently convicted and executed, the 1-year time bar will also apply. Likewise if he was convicted of a drug trafficking offence and executed, the 1-year time bar will also apply.

    Sir, I now move on to clause 10 which amends section 29 to enable the Minister to prescribe conditions for members to be exempted from taking the Home Protection Insurance Scheme. The need for this arose from the Board's experience of a sharp increase in the number of cases applying for such exemption on account of their private insurance coverage. In other words, there are CPF members who buy a HDB flat and say that they already have an existing private insurance policy which will ensure that they can pay up their mortgage and they ask for an exemption, and such exemption is then given.
